      74             : 
      75             : /*
      76             :  * A promise manages an asynchronous request that may or may not be able to be
      77             :  * fulfilled immediately. When an API returns a promise, the consumer may attach
      78             :  * callbacks to be invoked (asynchronously, on a specified thread) when the
      79             :  * request is either completed (resolved) or cannot be completed (rejected).
      80             :  * Whereas JS promise callbacks are dispatched from Microtask checkpoints,
      81             :  * MozPromises resolution/rejection make a normal round-trip through the event
      82             :  * loop, which simplifies their ordering semantics relative to other native code.
      83             :  *
      84             :  * MozPromises attempt to mirror the spirit of JS Promises to the extent that
      85             :  * is possible (and desirable) in C++. While the intent is that MozPromises
      86             :  * feel familiar to programmers who are accustomed to their JS-implemented cousin,
      87             :  * we don't shy away from imposing restrictions and adding features that make
      88             :  * sense for the use cases we encounter.
      89             :  *
      90             :  * A MozPromise is ThreadSafe, and may be ->Then()ed on any thread. The Then()
      91             :  * call accepts resolve and reject callbacks, and returns a magic object which
      92             :  * will be implicitly converted to a MozPromise::Request or a MozPromise object
      93             :  * depending on how the return value is used. The magic object serves several
      94             :  * purposes for the consumer.
      95             :  *
      96             :  *   (1) When converting to a MozPromise::Request, it allows the caller to
      97             :  *       cancel the delivery of the resolve/reject value if it has not already
      98             :  *       occurred, via Disconnect() (this must be done on the target thread to
      99             :  *       avoid racing).
     100             :  *
     101             :  *   (2) When converting to a MozPromise (which is called a completion promise),
     102             :  *       it allows promise chaining so ->Then() can be called again to attach
     103             :  *       more resolve and reject callbacks. If the resolve/reject callback
     104             :  *       returns a new MozPromise, that promise is chained to the completion
     105             :  *       promise, such that its resolve/reject value will be forwarded along
     106             :  *       when it arrives. If the resolve/reject callback returns void, the
     107             :  *       completion promise is resolved/rejected with the same value that was
     108             :  *       passed to the callback.
     109             :  *
     110             :  * The MozPromise APIs skirt traditional XPCOM convention by returning nsRefPtrs
     111             :  * (rather than already_AddRefed) from various methods. This is done to allow elegant
     112             :  * chaining of calls without cluttering up the code with intermediate variables, and
     113             :  * without introducing separate API variants for callers that want a return value
     114             :  * (from, say, ->Then()) from those that don't.
     115             :  *
     116             :  * When IsExclusive is true, the MozPromise does a release-mode assertion that
     117             :  * there is at most one call to either Then(...) or ChainTo(...).
     118             :  */
     119             : 
     120           0 : class MozPromiseRefcountable
     121             : {
     122             : public:
     123           0 :   NS_INLINE_DECL_THREADSAFE_REFCOUNTING(MozPromiseRefcountable)
     124             : protected:

    1184             : 
    1185             : // Asynchronous Potentially-Cross-Thread Method Calls.
    1186             : //
    1187             : // This machinery allows callers to schedule a promise-returning function
    1188             : // (a method and object, or a function object like a lambda) to be invoked
    1189             : // asynchronously on a given thread, while at the same time receiving a
    1190             : // promise upon which to invoke Then() immediately. InvokeAsync dispatches a
    1191             : // task to invoke the function on the proper thread and also chain the
    1192             : // resulting promise to the one that the caller received, so that resolve/
    1193             : // reject values are forwarded through.
    1194             :

    1196             :
